pasuk.text: Heb. השבכה, grata in Medieval Latin, lattice. I say that they were accustomed to weave it as a warp and a woof with long boards and short ones, which is called lattes, lathe [in] Fr., cancelli [in Latin]; cancel in O.F., space behind the grating, and they would make it all of holes like a sort of net, and it is called prodne in O.F. And I heard that שְּׂבָכָה is vis in Fr. a screw, and in German schwindel stieg, a spiral staircase, as I explained in (I Kings 6:8): “and with winding stairs they would go up…”
Heb. וַיָחַל an expression of sickness.

text.title: and Jehoram reigned in his stead:

pasuk.text: He was his brother.

text.title: in the second year of Jehoram the son of Jehoshaphat:

pasuk.text: Is it possible to say this? Did he not reign in the nineteenth year of Jehoshaphat, for Ahaziah reigned in the seventeenth [year of Jehoshaphat] (I Kings 22:52), and reigned for two years (ibid.), and in a nearby chapter also it is written (3:1) In the eighteenth year of Jehoshaphat, Jehoram reigned. Now Jehoshaphat reigned twenty-five years before Jehoram his son reigned. But, Jehoshaphat was deservant of being killed in Ramoth Gilead, but as a reward for his crying out [to God,] God suspended his death for him seven years, and from that time Scripture counts [the years] to his son.
[lit. in a storm],] i.e., in a storm wind.
He wished to drive him away because of his [Elijah’s] humility, so that he would not see him being taken away.
but not our master. This teaches us that they were equal to Elijah.
He rolled it up in order that it would be easy to strike with it.
not exactly rolling but gathering together, which is called koulir in O.F.

text.title: You have made a difficult request:

pasuk.text: It is impossible to give you more than I have in my possession.

text.title: If you see me taken away from you:

pasuk.text: then I will be able to do for you more and more.

text.title: it will be so to you, and if not, it will not be:

pasuk.text: for I have not the ability.

text.title: My father! My father! The chariots of Israel:

pasuk.text: Jonathan [renders:] My master! My master! who benefited Israel with his prayer more than chariots and riders.

text.title: Where is the Lord, the God of Elijah?:

pasuk.text: that I was promised [who promised me: Kara] that a double portion of his spirit would rest upon me.

He too. In the Chapters of Rabbi Eliezer the son of Rabbi Jose the Galilean, [should read: In the Thirty-two Methods of Rabbi Eliezer the son of Rabbi Jose the Galilean. Shem Ephraim], Elisha’s splitting [the Jordan] was doubly as great as Elijah’s, for in the beginning there was the merit of them both, while here was his merit alone.

text.title: Perhaps a wind from the Lord has carried him off:

pasuk.text: Is it possible that on the day before, they said to him, “Do you know that today the Lord will take your master from you?” (v. 5) and now they did not know where he was? This teaches us that since the day when Elijah was hidden, the holy spirit departed from the prophets, and the holy spirit was no longer widespread throughout Israel.

He was ashamed because of them, lest they say that he does not want to go to meet his teacher. Since he took over his high position, he does not want him to return. All this I saw in Tosefta Sotah (12:5).

and because of the water, the land causes people to die, to send them to their graves. If so, what is the meaning of: “the city is a good place to live in?” From here we deduce that a place has charm for its inhabitants.

text.title: to the source of the water:

pasuk.text: from where the water flowed.
Heb. וּנְעָרִים, people empty [of any observance of commandments].

Go away from here, for you have made the place bald for us, for until now we would hire ourselves out to bring sweet water from a distance, and we would earn our livelihood thereby. And when the water became sweet, they lost their livelihood. Thus it is explained in Sotah (46b).
He saw that neither in them nor in their descendants would there be any ‘sap’ of good deeds.

text.title: And Jehoram the son of Ahab:

pasuk.text: This section too was written here to tell the miracle of Mesha the king of Moab, which was performed through Elisha, for Scripture enumerated for Elijah eight miracles and for Elisha sixteen, to fulfill “a double portion of your spirit to me” (above 2:9), and he wrote them all one juxtaposed to the other. I saw this in the Thirty-two Methods of R. Eliezer the son of R. Jose the Calilean. Now the dividing of the Jordan by Elisha is counted like two miracles of Elijah.

text.title: however, not like his father and mother:

pasuk.text: who added the worship of the Baal in order to provoke God.

text.title: Only to the sins of Jeroboam… did he cling:

pasuk.text: And so [did] all kings of Israel, for fear lest the kingdom return to the house of David if they would perform the pilgrimage on festivals. They, therefore, worshipped the calves.
Jonathan [however, renders נֹקֵד as] an owner of livestock.
Jonathan [renders:] pasture-fed rams, i.e., with their wool.

text.title: by way of the Desert of Edom:

pasuk.text: for the king of Edom, too, will go with us.
for they will die of thirst.

text.title: who poured water on Elijah’s hands:

pasuk.text: on Mt. Carmel, and with his pouring, his fingers became like springs of water, until the ditch filled up, and it is fitting for a miracle to be performed for us through him concerning water.

text.title: Don’t [say that], for the Lord has summoned…:

pasuk.text: Jonathan [paraphrases thus]: Please do not mention the sins of that wicked woman. Beg mercy for us, for the Lord has summoned…
Because of his anger, the Shechinah left him.
Pits full of water.

And furthermore, this miracle is slight and insignificant in the eyes of the Lord, and He will proceed to act wondrously with you [and perform] another miracle, and He will deliver Moab into your hands.

text.title: and you shall fell every good tree:

pasuk.text: Even though it is stated (Deut. 20:19): “You shall not destroy its trees,” here He permitted it for you, for this is a contemptible and insignificant nation before Him. And so [Scripture] states (Deut. 23:7): “You shall not seek their welfare and their good.” These are the good trees that are among them.
A sown field (Koumici in O.F.).

text.title: And it was in the morning when the meal offering was offered up:

pasuk.text: The water began falling from heaven in the morning in the land of Edom, and at the time of offering up the meal offering, it came surging into that valley, since the prophet had said, “You shall not see wind neither shall you see rain” (v. 17). In R. Tanhuma’s Midrash.
at the border that is called marche [in French].
Such is the nature of water; when the sun shines on it in the morning, it appears red at a distance. Now, since they had never seen water in that valley, they, therefore, thought that it was blood.
[i.e.,] they were demolishing the cities.

text.title: and the catapultists surrounded and struck it:

pasuk.text: and each one threw his stonefor they would take stones from the walls until they left all the stones of the walls in the wall with only their clay, i.e., their mortar; that is to say that there were no more stones in the wall. And afterwards the catapultists surrounded that which remained in the field where the wall was not broken, and broke it down.

text.title: And he took his firstborn son:

pasuk.text: In the Pesikta of the section of Shekalim it is expounded that he asked his servants ([in] Pesikta [and] Yalkut: his astrologers), “What is the character of this nation, that miracles such as these were performed for them?” They replied, “Their forefather, Abraham, had an only son. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, Sacrifice him before Me, and he wanted to sacrifice him to the Holy One, Blessed be He.” He said to them, “I too have a first born son. I will go and sacrifice him to the gods.”
Heb. חֹמָה. The ‘vav’ is missing, for he worshipped the sun, חַמָה [i.e., he sacrificed his son to the sun].
For their iniquities were remembered, that they too worship pagan deities and are not worthy of miracles.

text.title: of the wives of the disciples of the prophets:

pasuk.text: She was the wife of Obadiah. Every expression of b’nei han’viim, the sons of the prophets, in Scripture, is translated in Targum as the disciples of the prophets.

He was Jehoram the son of Ahab, who would lend him with interest what he used to sustain the prophets in his father’s time. In R. Tanhuma’s Midrash (Mishpatim 9): Therefore it is stated (below 9:24): “And he struck Jehoram between his arms which stretched out to take interest.”

enough oil for anointment, yet the “aleph” is part of the root like the aleph of (Job 13:17) and my speech in your ears, [Heb. וְאַחְוָתִי, from חוה], and the “aleph” of (Ezek. 21:20) the crying of [those struck down] by the sword, [Heb. אִבְחַת, from נבח], to bark.

text.title: And you shall close the door:

pasuk.text: It affords respect to the miracle if it comes about in secret.

text.title: and the full one you shall carry away:

pasuk.text: from before you, and you shall place another vessel in its place to fill it, but the jug of oil you shall not move from its place, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, is making it as a spring, and it is not customary for a spring to move from its place. I heard this Midrash Aggadah.
the vessels.
coming any more. [This is the] peshat. Mid. Aggadah in Gen. Rabbah 35 explains it literally: and the oil stood up, meaning that the price of oil went. up

She came to receive advice whether to sell or to wait until it would become more expensive. He said to her, Go sell, for there is enough for all your debt, and for you and your sons to live with the remainder until the dead come to life.
[lit. a great woman, i.e.,] an important woman. And I saw in Pirkei d’R. Eliezer (ch. 33): She was the sister of Abishag the Shunemitess [who warmed King David in his old age].

text.title: and it was, whenever he would pass:

pasuk.text: in that city, he would stop at her house to eat a meal.
Heb. יסר, lit. he would stop. This is] the present tense, [i.e.,] he would stop there.
For she never saw a fly on his table or semen on his sheet.

text.title: You have busied yourself on our account:

pasuk.text: [lit.] to us.

[lit. all this shudder, i.e.] to put your heart into this task, like (Is. 66:2) “and shudders concerning My word,” [i.e.] is diligent concerning the task that it be accomplished and puts his heart into it.

text.title: What is there to do for you?:

pasuk.text: What do you need that we do for you, for you busied yourself with all this for us.

text.title: “I dwell in the midst of my people.”:

pasuk.text: amidst my relatives. No one harms me. I have need neither for the King nor for the general of the army.
Elisha to Gehazi.

text.title: “Now what can we do for her?”:

pasuk.text: to reciprocate for this favor.

text.title: At this time next year when you will be alive like now:

pasuk.text: [lit. like the time, alive, i.e.] just as you are alive today, and well, so will you be alive next year at this time and embracing a son.
Do not say, “embracing a son.” Why do I need to embrace him if I will end up burying him? This is what she said to him when he died, “Did I not say, ‘Do not mislead me’?”
Do not show me something that will fail. You have power to beg mercy, and a son will be given to me. I beseech you, do not give me any but a child who will live.
like (Is. 58:11) “whose water will not fail.”

text.title: at this time a year later:

pasuk.text: like this time that she was alive and well. Therefore, the word is voweled כָּעֵת; [i.e., like] the [time].
I am sick in my head!
His father [said] to one of the servants, “Carry him to his mother” .
quickly.

text.title: Don’t keep back from riding because of me:

pasuk.text: Do not keep back the riding because of me.
This is an abbreviated verse, So he should have written, “And he asked her, and she said, We are well.”
to you, Do not fail your maidservant?
Do not mislead me concerning a mistaken thing.

[lit. do not bless him.] Do not ask him about his welfare. All this was done so that he would not be engaged in conversation, and he would ask him, “Where are you going?” And he would say, “To revive the dead.” Now, it is not respectful for the one through whom it is coming about, to praise himself He, however, did not do so. Instead, to every inquirer he would say, “My master sent me to revive the dead.”

text.title: and he prostrated himself upon him:

pasuk.text: Jonathan renders: וְאַלְהֵי עֲלוֹהִי This is an expression of weariness. [I.e., he lay exhausted upon him.] There is a similar word in the Baraitha of Haazinu and in Sifrei (references obscure). And Menahem interpreted [as follows]: The interpretation of the word according to its context, is: he prostrated himself upon him.
Place it on the stove
Heb. נָזִיד, a cooked dish.
This follows Jonathan.

[Heb.] oroth, garden rocket, which they call eruca [in Latin], which brightens the eyes, meir [in Heb.] (Yoma 18b). Others interpret ‘oroth’ as herbs, as (Is. 18: 4) “Like a clear heat on herbs (‘or’).”

text.title: and gathered from it wild mushrooms:

pasuk.text: Wild mushrooms grew from it. That is boljic in O.F: It is poisonous. [It is common that mushrooms grow from old tree stumps and the like. In this case, they grew from a vine.] And in the name of Rabbi Menahem. I heard, and he gathered in addition to the fruit that grew from it, wild mushrooms.
split them.
the name of a province. And Jonathan rendered: from the southland.“Baal” is an expression meaning a plain. There are many such expressions in the Bible.
It was during Passover, when the grain becomes ripe.
Jonathan [renders]: in their garments. [The shell is compared to a garment of the grain].
to the students whom he sustained.
[i.e.,] each bread.
He goes on to recount the miracles that were performed through Elisha.
He drew back his bow innocently and killed Ahab.
When they go in groups of one hundred or two hundred by themselves, to plunder whatever they find, that is called a band.
Heb. naarah ketannah, a young girl from the town of Naaran.
[lit. and she was before Naaman’s wife.] Jonathan [renders]: and she was serving before Naaman’s wife.

before the prophet Heb. אֲחֲלֵי, an expression similar to וַיְחַל מֹשֶה, “and Moses prayed” (Ex. 32:11). The supplications of all those who pray for him, shall be that the miracle shall come before the prophet.
אַחֲלֵי I.e., to say that this is the supplication that he requires.
[i.e.,] Naaman [came]
the king of Aram.

text.title: and he took in his possession:

pasuk.text: as a gift to the prophet.
[lit.] and six thousand gold.
[“And now when this letter comes…5”]-The letter said to him, “And now, when this letter…”

text.title: and you shall cure him of his zaraath:

pasuk.text: [lit. and you shall gather him in from his zaraath.] Gathering, as applied to the mezora, is the expression of his cure, for when he is cured, he is gathered in among people, whereas during his illness, everyone stays away from him.

text.title: Do I have power from God:

pasuk.text: [after] Jonathan. [Lit. Am I God?] The ‘heh’ at the beginning of the word הַאֱלֹהִים, is voweled with a ‘pathah’ to indicate that it is a question.

text.title: he is looking for a pretext:

pasuk.text: He is looking for a pretext to engage in strife with me. [Heb. מִתְאַנֶה] an expression of pretext.
[I thought that] the prophet would come out and speak with me, and see the ailment.

text.title: and he would raise his hand toward the spot:

pasuk.text: of the] zaraath.
[lit. father].
Would you not do it even if he ordered you to do something requiring exertion?
by a fortiori conclusion, since he said to you to do an easy thing, [viz.] immerse yourself and become clean.
[lit. a blessing], a gift of peace, of greeting, when a disciple or a slave greets his master (sallud in O.F., a greeting).
for the price of idols was included in it.
וָלֹא, an expression of a request, an expression of הַלְוַאי.
from this soil of the land of Israel, which is holy, a load of earth as carried by a team of mules, and I will carry it off to my city, and I will make it into an altar.
the name of a pagan deity.
against my will when my master bows, since he leans on my hand.
[Heb.] kivrath eretz, the name of a land measure, like (Is. 5:10) “ten acres of vineyard.” (arpent in French), an old French measure of land, equivalent to about an acre.
Heb. מאומה The “aleph” is missing, since this taking was responsible for his being stricken with a blemish. מוּם [in Heb.].
Jonathan. [Lit. and he fell.]
swear that he sent you.

Heb. חֲרִטִים types of garments and kerchiefs, like (Is. 3:22) “and the kerchiefs and the ‘haritim.’” Menahem classified it thus (p. 94). Jonathan, however, translated this as ‘paldesin,’ sheets, (see Targum Jud. 14) and the one in the book of Isaiah as ‘mahachaia,’ a plate covering the genitals. The exegetes say that בִּשְׁנֵי חֲרִטִים, [means] ‘in two long pockets’ brids in O.F.
[i.e.,] Naaman’s.

text.title: and they carried them before him:

pasuk.text: before Gehazi.

text.title: And he came to a secret place:

pasuk.text: Jonathan renders: to a hidden place.

text.title: and he took them from their hands:

pasuk.text: from the hands of Naaman’s two servants.
lest Elisha see them.

text.title: Is it time to take the silver:

pasuk.text: to become wealthy and to buy with it clothing and olive trees…

text.title: And the disciples of the prophets said:

pasuk.text: He continues to enumerate the miracles that were performed for him (sic). Our Sages deduced from here that Gehazi would reject the pupils from before him, and when he was banished, many pupils came, and the place became too cramped for them.
Heb. הואל.
I borrowed it, and I have not the wherewithal to pay.
floated on the water.
Jonathan [renders]: covered and hidden. פְּלֹנִי is an expression of (Deut. 17:8) “If it be concealed” (יִפָּלֵא).
without a name, for he did not want it to be revealed.
There I will encamp and ambush the king of Israel or his bands who pass to plunder in my land through that place.
[i.e.,] from going there.
Heb. נְחִתִּים.

text.title: And the king of Israel sent:

pasuk.text: He would send and see whether it was true.
concerning which the man of God had cautioned him from passing.
did he do so for him, but many times.
who was revealing his secret.
where he is.
[i.e.,] who are on our side (helping us).

On the curse he did not mention the Name [of God,] but on opening the eyes he mentioned the Name [of God] on both of them, concerning [opening] the attendant’s [eyes], and concerning [opening the eyes] of the troop.
a sickness of confusion; one sees, yet does not know what he sees.
wherein the prophet is [found]. Now he told them the truth since he had already left it.

text.title: Do you slay those you have captured with your sword and with your bow:

pasuk.text: Is it your custom to slay one whom you bring into captivity (and destroy them)?
Heb. וַיִכְרֶה an expression of preparation of a meal.
[Heb.] divyonim; dung that flows from the doves.
He thought she was asking for food.
dead, and wants to eat him alone.
the sackcloth under his garments through the tear.

text.title: If Elisha the son of Shaphat’s head remain:

pasuk.text: for he is able to beg for mercy.

text.title: and he sent a man from before him:

pasuk.text: The king sent [a man] to kill him, and when that messenger had not yet come to Elisha, [and he was] revealed to him through the divine spirit, and he said to the elders…. and behold the messenger was coming down to him and the king was after him.
The king [said]

text.title: Behold, this calamity is from the Lord:

pasuk.text: This is one of the curses that He cursed through Moses, (Deut. 28:53) “And you will eat the fruit of your womb… during the siege and in the straitness…”

text.title: What more can I hope for from the Lord?:

pasuk.text: to save? It will surely not avail.
Gehazi and his sons.

text.title: at the entrance of the gate:

pasuk.text: as it is said (Lev. 13:46) “He shall live alone; outside the camp shall be his habitation.”

text.title: had caused the Aramean camp to hear:

pasuk.text: It seemed to them as though they were hearing.
We will be held guilty by the throne.
as they were full at the beginning; they did not take out what was in them.
and long to go out to the loot and to the food.
within the city, that did not die of hunger.

text.title: Behold, they are like all the multitude of Israel that are left there:

pasuk.text: If they will say that they are imperiled lest the Arameans kill them, behold they are in this city in peril of famine like the rest of all the multitude of Israel that are left there, and if they die, they are like all the multitude of Israel that have perished from hunger.
in their hurry to flee.
on the day before, when he came to Elisha’s house.

text.title: Now Elisha had spoken to the woman:

pasuk.text: already seven years before.

text.title: for the Lord has decreed a famine:

pasuk.text: This is the famine that took place in the days of Joel the son of Pethuel.

text.title: about her house and about her field:

pasuk.text: which robbers occupied.
to influence Gehazi to repent.
Toward Hazael he said that he would live instead of Ben Hadad and occupy the throne.
[lit. he made his face stand. I.e.,] he held in his expression of grief, for he wanted to cry, so as not to cry before Hazael, and he made an effort to stand and control himself.
ad bosh, [lit. until he delayed,] like “boshesh” (Ex. 32:1), and he could not control himself and wept.
[Heb.] תְּרַטֵשׁ an expression of splitting the intestines. The origin of all of them [is] (Is. 13:18)…“and bows will split (תְּרַטֵּשְׁנָה) the youths.”
their pregnant women.
Jonathan renders: “gunva.” [Likewise], (Jud. 4: 18) “And she covered him with a blanket,” he renders, ‘b’gunva.’ It is a garment.

text.title: and spread it on his face:

pasuk.text: so that he cool off.

Jehoshaphat crowned Joram two years during his lifetime. When they returned from the war they had waged with the king of Moab. So it was taught in Seder Olam (ch. 17), in the fifth year of Jehoram, and as regards the fifth year since Jehoshaphat, it was decreed on Jehoshaphat to be killed in Ramoth Gilead, but he was reprieved for seven years because he cried out [to God].
[Heb.] נִיר.

text.title: and they appointed a king over themselves:

pasuk.text: Since the time of David they did not have a king, as it is said. (II Sam. 8:14) “And he placed governors in Edom.” Eight kings reigned in Edom before a king reigned in Israel, viz. those enumerated in the Book of Genesis (36:31). Corresponding to them, eight kings reigned in Israel: Ish bosheth, David, Solomon, Rehoboam, Abiam, Asa, Jehoshaphat, and Jehoram. And Edom had no king. What is written above (3:9) that the king of Edom went with Jehoram the son of Ahab and with Jehoshaphat to war against the king of Moab, presents no difficulty because he was not a real king, but a governor, who is also called a king, and as it is said: (I Kings 22:48) “There was no king in Edom; a governor was king.” They had a governor in lieu of a king.
those near the border.

The inhabitants of Libnah rebelled and rebelled (sic) against the king. I do not know from what nation they were, since Libnah is from Eretz Israel. But I say that they were of the tribe of Judah and rebelled against the king.

text.title: and was buried with his forefathers in the city of David:

pasuk.text: And in II Chron. (21:20) it is stated: in the city of David, but not in the graves of the kings.
at that same time that Jehoram was ill in Jezreel.

text.title: one of the disciples of the prophets:

pasuk.text: It was Jonah the son of Amittai.
Every girding of the loins is an expression of quickening of mightiness. Since he was a messenger for a perilous mission, (he needed quickening).

text.title: the lad, the disciple of the prophet:

pasuk.text: the disciple of Elisha the prophet, so did Jonathan render: and the lad, the disciple of the prophet, went.
You recognize the man, that he is mad.

text.title: And they said, It is a lie:

pasuk.text: that you are saying. You are hiding what he said to you.

Jonathan [renders]: on the step of the hours, a type of steps made corresponding to the hours of the day, to know each hour when the shade descends one hour. [It was a type of sundial. The word used for step is] gerem, ourle in Old French, an expression of a notch. [Similarly, the word] “Hagramah,” in the laws of “shechitah” is from this derivation, that one slaughters in a straight line, and then cuts downwards, making an appearance of a hillock above.
that I reign.
from Ramoth-Gilead.
[Heb.] לַגִּיד, same as לְהַגִּיד.
how you and I were riding together after Ahab on the day that he killed Naboth.

text.title: when the Lord pronounced… upon him:

pasuk.text: this prophecy through the prophet Elijah, and we heard.

And in II Chron. (22:9), it is said: “And he sought Ahaziah, and they captured him when he was hiding in Samaria, and they brought him to Jehu.” [The discrepancy between] the verses can be reconciled [thus]: And… fled by way of the garden (sic) from Jezreel to Samaria. There is, however, an uncertainty in the matter, for Jehu had no rule in Samaria until the next day, as it is explained in this account (10:1): “And Jehu wrote letters and sent to Samaria…” Our Rabbis explained in the Aggadah of [the chapter] entitled ‘Chelek’ (San. 102b): “And he was hiding in Samaria, that he would cut out the Divine Names [from the Scriptures] and write [the names of] pagan deities in their place.” According to them, we can say that this hiding was not because of Jehu, but thus is its explanation: And he sought Ahaziah, and they captured him when he was fleeing by way of the garden (sic), and he had been behaving wickedly from the beginning, for he would come to Samaria and hide from the Judean officers to commit this abomination, since the inhabitants of Samaria were idolaters. “And they brought him to Jehu,” [i.e.,] Jehu’s men, who had pursued him. “And he said, ‘strike him… in the chariot.’”
for there they brought him to him.

text.title: And in the eleventh year of Joram son of Ahab, Ahaziah became king:

pasuk.text: Above (8:25) it is stated, “In the twelfth year.” And you are forced to say that Jehoram his father did not die until the twelfth year of Joram, for in the fifth year of Joram he became king (8:16) and he reigned for eight years (8:17). Now why does it say here, “In the eleventh year?” I say that he reigned one year during his father’s lifetime since he was afflicted with severe maladies, as it is said: “And after all this, the Lord afflicted him with incurable illness. And it was by the end of a year, that his intestines went out because of his illness… And the inhabitants of Jerusalem made Ahaziah… king” (II Chron 21:18-22:1.) Here (8:26) it is stated: “Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he reigned, and in II Chron. (22:2), ” He was (sic) forty-two years old when he reigned.“ Now all the days of Jehoram his father was forty years, no more, as it is said concerning him: ” He was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned eight years (8:17).“ Now how is it possible for a son to be two years older than his father? Rather, twenty years before he was born, which was two years before his father was born, this decree was issued. From the day that Asa took a daughter of Omri in marriage for Jehoshaphat his son, a decree was issued upon the house of David that it be destroyed with the house of Ahab. And thus it is stated in II Chron. (22:7) ” And from God was Ahaziah’s confusion, to come to Joram…“ Thus it is taught in Seder Olam (ch. 17) and in the Tosefta of Sotah (ch. 12). Nowhere in the Scriptures, however, do we find that Jehoshaphat married Omri’s daughter. I did find, however, in II Chron. (18: 1) ” And he (Jehoshaphat) intermarried with Ahab.“ Perhaps this refers to his sister whom he married. And in the thirty- first year of Asa he married her, as it is said: ” In the thirty- first year of Asa… Omri reigned" (I Kings 15:23). And we learned in Seder Olam (ch. 17) that he reigned over the entire kingdom, for six years prior to then, he reigned over half the people, and when Asa took his daughter in marriage to Jehoshaphat, he gained prestige, and they assassinated Tibni. Proceed and calculate from the thirty first year of Asa until the death of Ahaziah and you will find them to be forty two.
She adorned her head in order to have charm in Jehu’s eyes so that he would marry her.
Do you wish to be with me in peace?
If you assassinated your master, this is nothing new, for Zimri too assassinated Elah son of Baasha.
Who among you will come to my aid?

Our Rabbis said, that she would dance before bridegrooms with her hands and feet, and shake her head.
This follows Jonathan.

text.title: and to those who brought up Ahab’s children:

pasuk.text: lit. to those who brought up Ahab.

text.title: and the chariots and the horses… are with you:

pasuk.text: and they have strength to wage war.
Joram and Ahaziah.

text.title: Now the king’s sons are seventy men. They are with the elders of the city…:

pasuk.text: All this was written in the letter, “And I know their count seventy men and they are with the elders of the city who are bringing them up.”
[Heb. צִבֻּרִים]. Synonymous with חֳמָרִים in Heb. and דְּגוֹרִין in Aramaic (monticules in French, mounds).

You consider yourselves all righteous, and me you consider wicked since I slew the king. Now look, behold I revolted against my master and slew him. Now who slew all these? But from these you shall know then that it is a decree of the King upon them, and he who slays is righteous and fulfills the commandment of the Omnipresent.

text.title: the meeting place of the shepherds:

pasuk.text: Jonathan [renders]: the house of the gathering of the shepherds.
[Heb. עקד], an expression of binding, the place where the shepherds assemble.
[i.e.,] Jehu [said to Jehonadeb].
and fully committed in what I am doing, as my heart is fully with your heart?”

text.title: “Indeed it is. Give me your hand.”:

pasuk.text: Hold it and pick me up to you to the chariot.
[Heb. בְּעָקְבָה] with [guile, an expression of] (Gen. 27:36) וַיַעְקְבֵנִי, “he beguiled me.”
Announce an assembly, that they assemble in the temple of the Baal.
Jonathan rendered: to the one appointed over the wardrobe, chests and boxes in which they wrap and store the vestments of the Baal worshippers.

text.title: his life shall be forfeit for his life:

pasuk.text: [i.e.,] the life of the guard shall be forfeit for the life of the escapee.
Jonathan [renders]: and the couriers and the mighty warriors cast cadavers, [i.e.,] they cast the Baal worshippers down dead.
[the] Kethib is לִמְחֹרָאוֹת, an expression meaning a privy, and likewise, (Isaiah 36:12) “to eat their excrement, חוריהם.”

text.title: However,… from the sins of Jeroboam…:

pasuk.text: for fear that the kingdom return to the house of David, as Jeroboam had feared.

text.title: And the Lord said to Jehu:

pasuk.text: through Jonah.

text.title: your descendants of the fourth generation:

pasuk.text: four generations as reward for your having destroyed the house of Ahab, which reigned for four generations: Omri, Ahab, Ahaziah, and Jehoram.
[Heb. לְקַצוֹת,] like (Gen. 27:46) בְחַיַי קַצְתִּי, “I am vexed with my life.”

in the attic of the Holy of Holies, as it says (v. 3): And he was… with her in the house of the Lord. [It was] concerning him that David said, (Ps. 27:5) “For He will conceal me in His Tabernacle, He will hide me in the secrecy of His tent” [Seder Olam, ch. 18]. He calls it the bed- chamber in the manner of (Song of Songs 1:13) “Between my breasts He lodges.” This is what R. Eliezer instituted, “The destruction of the bed-chamber, [may He remember for an atonement” ; i.e.,] may the destruction of Your Temple atone for them.

[Heb. לַכָּרִי,] the officers of the hundreds of the mighty warriors and the officers of the hundreds of the couriers. The expression כָּרִי, which he used, and did not say לַכָּרִים, is a noun meaning a company of mighty warriors (barned in O. F.), nobility.

text.title: and he enacted a covenant with them:

pasuk.text: that they would aid him in crowning the king’s son.

text.title: a third of you, of those who come on the Sabbath:

pasuk.text: The watches would be renewed on the Sabbath (see Taanith 2:6,7), the watches of the priests and the Levites. One would enter and one would leave. He ordered the “mishmar” that was entering, to separate into three parts, one third in the king’s palace, to guard that no one rise up against the king to assassinate him, one third in the Sur Gate, that is the eastern gate of the Temple court, the Hasarah Gate (sic). One third in the gate [called,] “After the Couriers.” That too was one of the gates of the Temple court. Jonathan rendered: in the gate behind which was the gate of the couriers. Through the gate of the couriers one would go from the royal palace to the Temple, as it is stated at the end of this episode (v. 19). And that gate about which it is stated that the Gate of the couriers was behind it, was called in II Chron. (23:4) the gate of the Sippim.

text.title: and you shall keep the watch of the palace without taking your mind off it:

pasuk.text: This watch he commanded them (sic) the first division, concerning whom he said, “And they shall keep the watch of the king’s palace” (sic).

text.title: from taking your mind off it:

pasuk.text: Guard it very diligently, that you do not take your mind off it, an expression of despair (I Sam. 27:2), that there should be no despair in this matter. The ‘mem’ of מַסָּח is part of the root. [I.e., it is part of a noun. It is not a prefix meaning from.]
who I said should be in the Sur Gate and in the Gate of the Couriers, and with them all those who leave on the Sabbath, the men of the departing mishmar.

text.title: shall keep the watch of the house of the Lord, to guard the king:

pasuk.text: lest harm befall him from within the house of the Lord. Now he did not require all this except on the first Sabbath, until Athaliah was killed and her allies fled from the city.

text.title: and the one who comes within the ranks:

pasuk.text: a stranger who comes within the boundary called “sederoth,” which is the place of the king’s entry from his palace to the house of the Lord. I did not know the origin of the word “sederoth,” and Jonathan rendered it as “rows” [like] “sedarim” [with a] “samech.”

the scroll of the Law, as it is written: “And it shall be with him, and he shall read in it all the days of his life” (Deut. 17:19). And our Rabbis said that the crown itself was the testimony, for anyone who is fit for the throne it would fit, whereas anyone unfit for the throne it would not fit.
That is the place where the king stands in the house of the Lord.
Revolt! There is a revolt here.
